title: Keygen 3
statementHtml:
A permutation∗∗ of length nn is called valid if it has both of the following properties:

Let kk denote the number of permutations satisfying the above condition. Your task is to find and print min(k,2000)min(k,2000) examples of such permutations.

†† A permutation p1,p2,…,pnp1,p2,…,pn is bitonic if there exists an index ii (1≤i≤n1≤i≤n) such that

‡‡ A subset C⊆{1,2,…,n}C⊆{1,2,…,n} is a cycle if it satisfies the following conditions:

∗∗A permutation of length nn is an array consisting of nn distinct integers from 11 to nn in arbitrary order. For example, [2,3,1,5,4][2,3,1,5,4] is a permutation, but [1,2,2][1,2,2] is not a permutation (22 appears twice in the array), and [1,3,4][1,3,4] is also not a permutation (n=3n=3 but there is 44 in the array).
inputSpecHtml: The input consists of a single line containing two integers nn, mm (1≤m≤n≤1001≤m≤n≤100) — the length of the permutations and the target number of cycles.
outputSpecHtml:
In the first line, print a single integer rr: the number of permutations you are going to print. Note that rr must be min(k,2000)min(k,2000) as defined in the statement.

Then, print rr lines. Each line must contain a bitonic permutation of length nn, with mm cycles.
noteHtml: In the example, there are 99 valid permutations (i.e., bitonic permutations of length 66, with 33 cycles). For example, [3,5,6,4,2,1][3,5,6,4,2,1] is bitonic (in the above definition, i=3i=3), and it has 33 cycles: {1,3,6}{1,3,6}, {2,5}{2,5}, {4}{4}. So you have to print r=min(9,2000)=9r=min(9,2000)=9 such permutations.
